thread.title: Storm Doris claims its first victim as woman dies outside Wolverhampton Starbucks store as 94mph winds batter UK
thread.title_full: Storm Doris claims its first victim as woman dies outside Wolverhampton Starbucks store as 94mph winds batter UK

author: lburnip
title: Storm Doris claims its first victim as woman dies outside Wolverhampton Starbucks store as 94mph winds batter UK

organizations.name: east sussex london news pictures waves
transpennine express and virgin trains east coast

text:
Opinion KILLER STORM Storm Doris claims its first victim as woman dies outside Wolverhampton Starbucks store as 94mph winds batter UK 
Flash floods and debris strewn across roads are already causing chaos as winds of 94mph race across the nation By LAURA BURNIP AND JOHN SHAMMAS 23rd February 2017, 1:00 pm Comments A WOMAN has been killed in a Storm Doris-related incident outside a Starbucks in Wolverhampton. 
West Midlands Police received 15 calls just before midday about the incident, in Dudley Street, and later confirmed the death. The incident, in Dudley Street, sparked 15 calls to 999, with West Midlands Police later confirming the death Getty Images An adult and child cross London Bridge in strong winds as Storm Doris heads eastwards 
Local ambulance service workers took to social media to confirm that they were responding to the incident. 
They wrote: “We can confirm that we are currently dealing with a very serious incident in Dudley Street, Wolverhampton. 
“Two ambulances, an area support officer and two critical care paramedics were sent to the scene after 15 999 calls at 11.43am this morning. 
“We will provide further updates as and when able.” 
Reports claimed that debris has struck the woman falling from a Starbucks shop. 
A spokeswoman told The Sun Online: “We are shocked and saddened by this terrible incident. 
“We are supporting the police with their investigation and our store will remain closed until further notice.” 
Locals described the scene as “utter chaos”. 
In nearby West Brom, High Street has also been closed by West Midlands Police “due to falling debris”. 
Officers added: “Please avoid the area.” SWNS:South West News Service A pushchair is lifted off the ground by strong winds in Blackpool Getty Images Waves crash into Newhaven Lighthouse in east Sussex as Storm Doris powers across Britain PA:Press Association Wire Traffic on the M876 near Falkirk as snow falls this morning, with a foot expected to settle in the coming hours PA:Press Association People walk through Mauricewood Park, Penicuik, Midlothian PA:Press Association A commuter waits for a bus in Mauricwood Road, Penicuik, Midlothian SWNS:South West News Service Dramatic images show how the swirling storm will sweep across the UK this morning Snow falls across Scotland overnight as Storm Doris hits UK scott@scottbairstowphotography.co.uk Signs warning drivers of treacherous conditions were spotted on the M1 in Barnsley, South Yorks., this morning SWNS:South West News Service A tree blocks Bath Road, Bristol, after being blown down yesterday in strong winds PA:Press Association 25 A plane takes off in wet weather this morning from Leeds Bradford Airport, but dozens of flights have been grounded as Storm Doris 
A 94mph gust was recorded in Capel Curig, north west Wales, this morning as the storm powers its way eastwards, with snow causing roads to be shut in Scotland and winds forcing major bridges across the UK to close. 
All trains travelling in and out of London Euston have been suspended with others urged to put off travelling until tomorrow. 
A 13-year-old boy was rushed to hospital after being hit by a tree which crashed down onto a group of teenagers as the storm raged. 
He suffered minor injuries after being hit in the back by the tree in Arnos Vale, Bristol, and police said a raised concrete wall prevented the tree from crushing the boy entirely. 
A tree falling in Plymouth, Cornwall, this morning also missed a cyclist "by seconds", police told the Plymouth Herald. 
A lorry has blown over on the A14 in Cambridgeshire, with police warning of delays. 
The Dartford Crossing bridge has been shut due to strong winds after reports of five-mile tailbacks this morning. 
Orwell Bridge in Ipswich, the M48 Severn Bridge and the A548 Flintshire Bridge are also closed, as well as the M6 both ways at Thelwall Viaduct. 
Commuters are being warned not to make unnecessary journeys with flights grounded and speed limits imposed on trains amid widespread disruption. 
An amber severe weather warning has now been extended to London with forecasters warning of very strong winds which could blow down trees, causing flying debris and damage buildings. 
A yellow warning for ice has also been issued for tonight with warnings of "wintry showers" in north-east England, with temperatures across the country expected to plummet to between 1C and 3C overnight. 
People coming into and out of St Pancras are facing delays until 12pm after overhead wires in St Albans were blown down. Your rights if your flight has been delayed or cancelled - here's what you should do 
IF your flight’s been cancelled or delayed because of Storm Doris then it's crucial that you know your rights, so that you don’t end up out of pocket. Under EU rules if your flight is cancelled at short notice then they should give you a full refund or offer suitable alternative travel. If your flight is delayed then you are only entitled to compensation if the delay was caused by something within the airline’s control. Extraordinary circumstances aren’t covered but you should still try and ask the airline if they will compensate you. If your departure is delayed for over five hours then you can choose not to travel and get a refund. Apex News A dog plays in foam in the sea whipped up by high winds in St Ives, Cornwall Maverick Photography High winds ripped the roof off a Lidl store in Blackpool Maverick Photography Part of the roof could be seen laying on the ground after Doris swept into Blackpool today SWNS:South West News Service Blackpool fire crews make a roof safe on a house after part of it blew away in strong winds Reuters Waves crash against the pier in Blackpool, Lancs., as Doris hit the west coast of Britain this morning #StormDoris will move east today bringing #wind gusts as high as 80mph, causing some disruption #weatheraware pic.twitter.com/793fKpeOF7 
— Met Office (@metoffice) February 23, 2017 
In Blackpool, the roof of a Lidl store was ripped off by strong gales. 
The roof of Lichfield train station, Staffs., has also been blown off by high winds. 
Several roads in Scotland have had to close after heavy snow meant drivers had to abandon their cars. 
Aer Lingus has cancelled almost all flights between Ireland and England after a plane was filmed appearing to struggle as it landed in cross-winds at Leeds Bradford Airport yesterday. 
Heathrow Airport advised passengers to check their flight status before arriving at the airport. 
In Dublin, Twitter users reported flooding being pumped from streets near the Liffey and debris all over the roads. 
46,000 homes across Dublin, Sligo, Galway, Leitrim and Mayo are also without power. Plane tilts from side-to-side as it lands in windy Storm Doris weather at Leeds-Bradford airport Water gushes into man's home in Dublin as Storm Doris hits UK 
In Mumbles Head, south Wales, gusts of 75mph were recorded this morning, while in Aberdaron in west Wales winds reached 72mph. 
The Met Office confirmed the storm had "rapidly deepened" into a weather bomb over the last 24 hours. 
A yellow severe weather warning of "be aware" is also in place in the Midlands, northern England, Wales and Scotland as Storm Doris makes her way towards the UK. 
The storm is expected to peak at around midday but gale-force gusts, torrential rain and snow are already causing chaos in Ireland, Scotland and west Wales. Weather warnings in place as Storm Doris makes it's way across the UK Pacemaker Press Storm Doris brings down a large tree in Lambeg Road between Lisburn and Belfast Twitter / @Balrothery An old beech tree is felled by strong winds in Balrothery Glebe park PA:Press Association Waves crash over the marina wall in Brighton, East Sussex London News Pictures Waves crash against a lighthouse in Aberystwyth, west Wales Huge waves crash against Aberystwyth promenade as Storm Doris hits UK 
Winds as fast as 60mph are also expected to batter southern England, and the Met Office has put the whole country on alert over Storm Doris . 
Train services will be disrupted with Network Rail imposing a 50mph speed limit on the West Coast Mainline, Southeastern, Arriva Trains Wales, Chiltern Railways, Grand Central, TransPennine Express and Virgin Trains East Coast. 

Richard Leonard, head of road safety at Highways England, said: "We're expecting Storm Doris to have a significant impact on the roads throughout the day so are urging drivers to consider changing their plans if necessary and to slow down in stormy weather. 
"Drivers should look out for warnings on the electronic message signs and listen for updates in radio travel bulletins."
